A milk-white Hind, immortal and unchang'd,</br>Fed on the lawns, and in the forest rang'd;</br>Without unspotted, innocent within,</br>She fear'd no danger, for she knew no sin.</br>Yet had she oft been chas'd with horns and hounds,</br>And Scythian shafts; and many winged wounds</br>Aim'd at Her heart; was often forc'd to fly,</br>And doom'd to death, though fated not to dy.

Not so her young; for their unequal line</br>Was Heroe's make, half human, half divine.</br>Their earthly mold obnoxious was to fate,</br>Th' immortal part assum'd immortal state.</br>Of these a slaughtered army lay in bloud,</br>Extended o'er the Caledonian wood,</br>Their native walk; whose vocal bloud arose,</br>And cry'd for pardon on their perjur'd foes;</br>Their fate was fruitfull, and the sanguin seed</br>Endu'd with souls, increas'd the sacred breed.</br>So Captive Israel multiply'd in chains</br>A numerous Exile, and enjoy'd her pains.</br>With grief and gladness mixt, their mother view'd</br>Her martyr'd offspring, and their race renew'd;</br>Their corps to perish, but their kind to last,</br>So much the deathless plant the dying fruit surpass'd.

Panting and pensive now she rang'd alone,</br>And wander'd in the kingdoms, once Her own.</br>The common Hunt, though from their rage restrain'd</br>By sov'reign pow'r, her company disdain'd:</br>Grin'd as They pass'd, and with a glaring eye</br>Gave gloomy signs of secret enmity.</br>'Tis true, she bounded by, and trip'd so light,</br>They had not time to take a steady sight;</br>For truth has such a face and such a meen</br>As to be lov'd needs onely to be seen.

The bloudy Bear an Independent beast,</br>Unlick'd to form, in groans her hate express'd.</br>Among the timorous kind the Quaking Hare</br>Profess'd neutrality, but wou'd not swear.</br>Next her the Buffoon Ape, as Atheists use,</br>Mimick'd all Sects, and had his own to chuse:</br>Still when the Lyon look'd, his knees he bent,</br>And pay'd at Church a Courtier's Complement.</br>The bristl'd Baptist Boar, impure as He,</br>(But whiten'd with the foam of sanctity)</br>With fat pollutions fill'd the sacred place,</br>And mountains levell'd in his furious race,</br>So first rebellion founded was in grace.</br>But since the mighty ravage, which he made</br>In German Forests, had his guilt betrayd,</br>With broken tusks, and with a borrow'd name,</br>He shunn'd the vengeance, and conceal'd the shame;</br>So lurk'd in Sects unseen.  With greater guile</br>False Reynard fed on consecrated spoil:</br>The graceless beast by Athanasius first</br>Was chas'd from Nice, then by Socinus nurs'd;</br>His impious race their blasphemy renew'd,</br>And natures King through natures opticks view'd.</br>Revers'd they view'd him lessen'd to their eye,</br>Nor in an Infant could a God descry:</br>New swarming Sects to this obliquely tend,</br>Hence they began, and here they all will end.

What weight of antient witness can prevail,</br>If private reason hold the publick scale?</br>But, gracious God, how well dost thou provide</br>For erring judgments an unerring Guide?</br>Thy throne is darkness in th' abyss of light,</br>A blaze of glory that forbids the sight;</br>O teach me to believe Thee thus conceal'd,</br>And search no farther than thyself reveal'd;</br>But her alone for my Directour take</br>Whom thou hast promis'd never to forsake!</br>My thoughtless youth was wing'd with vain desires,</br>My manhood, long misled by wandring fires,</br>Follow'd false lights; and when their glimps was gone,</br>My pride struck out new sparkles of her own.</br>Such was I, such by nature still I am;</br>Be thine the glory, and be mine the shame.</br>Good life be now my task:  my doubts are done,</br>(What more could fright my faith, than Three in One?)</br>Can I believe eternal God could lye</br>Disguis'd in mortal mould, and infancy?</br>That the great Maker of the world could dye?</br>And after that, trust my imperfect sense,</br>Which calls in question his omnipotence?</br>Can I my reason to my faith compell,</br>And shall my sight, and touch, and taste rebell?</br>Superiour faculties are set aside,</br>Shall their subservient organs be my guide?</br>Then let the moon usurp the rule of day,</br>And winking tapers shew the sun his way;</br>For what my senses can themselves perceive</br>I need no revelation to believe.</br>Can they who say the Host should be descry'd</br>By sense, define a body glorify'd,</br>Impassible, and penetrating parts?</br>Let them declare by what mysterious arts</br>He shot that body through th' opposing might</br>Of bolts and barrs impervious to the light,</br>And stood before his train confess'd in open sight.

For since thus wondrously he pass'd, 'tis plain,</br>One single place two bodies did contain;</br>And sure the same omnipotence as well</br>Can make one body in more places dwell.</br>Let reason then at Her own quarry fly,</br>But how can finite grasp infinity?

'Tis urg'd again that faith did first commence</br>By miracles, which are appeals to sense,</br>And thence concluded that our sense must be</br>The motive still of credibility.</br>For latter ages must on former wait,</br>And what began belief, must propagate.

But winnow well this thought, and you shall find,</br>'Tis light as chaff that flies before the wind.</br>Were all those wonders wrought by pow'r divine</br>As means or ends of some more deep design?</br>Most sure as means, whose end was this alone,</br>To prove the god-head of th' eternal Son.</br>God thus asserted:  man is to believe</br>Beyond what sense and reason can conceive.</br>And for mysterious things of faith rely</br>On the Proponent, heav'ns authority.</br>If then our faith we for our guide admit,</br>Vain is the farther search of humane wit,</br>As when the building gains a surer stay,</br>We take th' unusefull scaffolding away:</br>Reason by sense no more can understand,</br>The game is play'd into another hand.</br>Why chuse we then like Bilanders to creep</br>Along the coast, and land in view to keep,</br>When safely we may launch into the deep?</br>In the same vessel, which our Saviour bore</br>Himself the Pilot, let us leave the shoar,</br>And with a better guide a better world explore.</br>Could He his god-head veil with flesh and bloud,</br>And not veil these again to be our food?</br>His grace in both is equal in extent,</br>The first affords us life, the second nourishment.</br>And if he can, why all this frantick pain,</br>To construe what his clearest words contain,</br>And make a riddle what He made so plain?</br>To take up half on trust, and half to try,</br>Name it not faith, but bungling biggottry;</br>Both knave and fool the Merchant we may call</br>To pay great summs, and to compound the small.</br>For who wou'd break with heav'n, and wou'd not break for all?</br>Rest then, my soul, from endless anguish freed;</br>Nor sciences thy guide, nor sense thy creed.</br>Faith is the best ensurer of thy bliss;</br>The Bank above must fail, before the venture miss.</br>But heav'n and heav'n-born faith are far from Thee,</br>Thou first Apostate to Divinity.</br>Unkennel'd range in thy Polonian Plains;</br>A fiercer foe th' insatiate Wolfe remains.

Too boastfull Britain, please thyself no more,</br>That beasts of prey are banish'd from thy shoar:</br>The Bear, the Boar, and every salvage name,</br>Wild in effect, though in appearance tame,</br>Lay waste thy woods, destroy thy blissfull bow'r,</br>And, muzl'd though they seem, the mutes devour.</br>More haughty than the rest, the wolfish race,</br>Appears with belly Gaunt, and famish'd face:</br>Never was so deform'd a beast of Grace.</br>His ragged tail betwixt his leggs he wears</br>Close clap'd for shame, but his rough crest he rears,</br>And pricks up his predestinating ears.</br>His wild disorder'd walk, his hagger'd eyes,</br>Did all the bestial citizens surprize.</br>Though fear'd and hated, yet he rul'd awhile</br>As Captain or Companion of the spoil.</br>Full many a year his hatefull head had been</br>For tribute paid, nor since in Cambria seen:</br>The last of all the litter scap'd by chance,</br>And from Geneva first infested France.</br>Some authours thus his pedigree will trace,</br>But others write him of an upstart race:</br>Because of Wickliffe's brood no mark he brings</br>But his innate antipathy to kings.</br>These last deduce him from th' Helvetian kind,</br>Who near the Leman lake his Consort lin'd.</br>That fi'ry Zuynglius first th' affection bred,</br>And meagre Calvin blest the nuptial bed.</br>In Israel some believe him whelp'd long since</br>When the proud Sanhedrim oppress'd the Prince.</br>Or, since he will be Jew, derive him high'r</br>When Corah with his brethren did conspire,</br>From Moyses hand the sov'reign sway to wrest,</br>And Aaron of his Ephod to divest:</br>Till opening earth made way for all to pass,</br>And cou'd not bear the burd'n of a class.</br>The Fox and he came shuffl'd in the dark,</br>If ever they were stow'd in Noah's ark:</br>Perhaps not made; for all their barking train</br>The Dog (a common species) will contain.</br>And some wild currs, who from their masters ran</br>Abhorring the supremacy of man,</br>In woods and caves the rebel-race began.

O happy pair, how well have you increas'd,</br>What ills in Church and State have you redress'd!</br>With teeth untry'd, and rudiments of claws</br>Your first essay was on your native laws:</br>Those having torn with ease, and trampl'd down,</br>Your Fangs you fasten'd on the mitr'd crown,</br>And freed from God and monarchy your town.</br>What though your native kennel still be small,</br>Bounded betwixt a puddle and a wall,</br>Yet your victorious colonies are sent</br>Where the north ocean girds the continent.</br>Quicken'd with fire below, your monsters breed,</br>In Fenny Holland, and in fruitfull Tweed.</br>And, like the first, the last affects to be</br>Drawn to the dreggs of a Democracy.</br>As, where in fields the fairy rounds are seen,</br>A rank sow'r herbage rises on the green,</br>So, springing where these mid-night Elves advance,</br>Rebellion prints the foot-steps of the Dance.</br>Such are their doctrines, such contempt they show</br>To heav'n above, and to their Prince below,</br>As none but Traytors and Blasphemers know.</br>God, like the Tyrant of the skyes is plac'd,</br>And kings like slaves beneath the crowd debas'd.</br>So fulsome is their food, that flocks refuse</br>To bite, and onely dogs for physick use.</br>As where the lightning runs along the ground,</br>No husbandry can heal the blasting wound</br>Nor bladed grass, nor bearded corn succeeds,</br>But scales of scurf, and putrefaction breeds:</br>Such warrs, such waste, such fiery tracks of dearth</br>Their zeal has left, and such a teemless earth.</br>But, as the Poisons of the deadliest kind</br>Are to their own unhappy coasts confin'd,</br>As only Indian shades of sight deprive,</br>And magick plants will but in Colchos thrive,</br>So Preby'try and pestilential zeal</br>Can only flourish in a common-weal.

From Celtique woods is chas'd the wolfish crew;</br>But ah!  some pity e'en to brutes is due:</br>Their native walks, methinks, they might enjoy</br>Curb'd of their native malice to destroy.</br>Of all the tyrannies on humane kind,</br>The worst is that which persecutes the mind.</br>Let us but weigh at what offence we strike,</br>'Tis but because we cannot think alike.</br>In punishing of this, we overthrow</br>The laws of nations and of nature too.</br>Beasts are the subjects of tyrannick sway,</br>Where still the stronger on the weaker prey.</br>Man onely of a softer mould is made;</br>Not for his fellows ruine, but their aid.</br>Created kind, beneficent and free,</br>The noble image of the Deity.

One portion of informing fire was giv'n</br>To brutes, th' inferiour family of heav'n.</br>The Smith divine, as with a careless beat,</br>Struck out the mute creation at a heat:</br>But, when arriv'd at last to humane race,</br>The god-head took a deep consid'ring space:</br>And, to distinguish man from all the rest,</br>Unlock'd the sacred treasures of his breast:</br>And mercy mix'd with reason did impart;</br>One to his head, the other to his heart;</br>Reason to rule, but mercy to forgive:</br>The first is law, the last prerogative.</br>And like his mind his outward form appeared;</br>When issuing naked to the wondring herd,</br>He charm'd their eyes, and for they lov'd, they fear'd.</br>Not arm'd with horns of arbitrary might,</br>Or claws to seize their furry spoils in fight,</br>Or with increase of feet t' o'ertake 'em in their flight.</br>Of easie shape, and pliant ev'ry way;</br>Confessing still the softness of his clay,</br>And kind as kings upon their coronation day:</br>With open hands, and with extended space</br>Of arms, to satisfie a large embrace.</br>Thus kneaded up with milk, the new made man</br>His kingdom o'er his kindred world began:</br>Till knowledge misapply'd, misunderstood,</br>And pride of Empire sour'd his balmy bloud.</br>Then, first rebelling, his own stamp he coins;</br>The murd'rer Cain was latent in his loins,</br>And bloud began its first and loudest cry</br>For diff'ring worship of the Deity.</br>Thus persecution rose, and farther space</br>Produc'd the mighty hunter of his race.</br>Not so the blessed Pan his flock increas'd,</br>Content to fold 'em from the famish'd beast:</br>Mild were his laws; the Sheep and harmless Hind</br>Were never of the persecuting kind.</br>Such pity now the pious Pastor shows,</br>Such mercy from the British Lyon flows,</br>That both provide protection from their foes.

O happy Regions, Italy and Spain,</br>Which never did those monsters entertain!</br>The Wolfe, the Bear, the Boar, can there advance</br>No native claim of just inheritance.</br>And self-preserving laws, severe in show,</br>May guard their fences from th' invading foe.</br>Where birth has plac'd 'em let 'em safely share</br>The common benefit of vital air.</br>Themselves unharmfull, let them live unharm'd;</br>Their jaws disabl'd, and their claws disarm'd:</br>Here, onely in nocturnal howlings bold,</br>They dare not seize the Hind nor leap the fold.</br>More pow'rfull, and as vigilant as they,</br>The Lyon awfully forbids the prey.</br>Their rage repress'd, though pinched with famine sore,</br>They stand aloof, and tremble at his roar;</br>Much is their hunger, but their fear is more.</br>These are the chief; to number o'er the rest,</br>And stand, like Adam, naming ev'ry beast,</br>Were weary work; nor will the Muse describe</br>A slimy-born and sun-begotten Tribe:</br>Who, far from steeples and their sacred sound,</br>In fields their sullen conventicles found:</br>These gross, half-animated lumps I leave;</br>Nor can I think what thoughts they can conceive.</br>But if they think at all, 'tis sure no high'r</br>Than matter, put in motion, may aspire.</br>Souls that can scarce ferment their mass of clay;</br>So drossy, so divisible are They,</br>As wou'd but serve pure bodies for allay:</br>Such souls as Shards produce, such beetle things</br>As only buz to heav'n with ev'ning wings;</br>Strike in the dark, offending but by chance,</br>Such are the blind-fold blows of ignorance.</br>They know not beings, and but hate a name;</br>To them the Hind and Panther are the same.

The Panther, sure the noblest, next the Hind,</br>And fairest creature of the spotted kind;</br>Oh, could her in-born stains be wash'd away,</br>She were too good to be a beast of Prey!</br>How can I praise, or blame, and not offend,</br>Or how divide the frailty from the friend!</br>Her faults and virtues lye so mix'd, that she</br>Nor wholly stands condemn'd, nor wholly free.</br>Then, like her injur'd Lyon, let me speak;</br>He cannot bend her, and he wou'd not break.</br>Unkind already, and estrang'd in part,</br>The Wolfe begins to share her wandring heart.</br>Though unpolluted yet with actual ill,</br>She half commits who sins but in Her will.</br>If, as our dreaming Platonists report,</br>There could be spirits of a middle sort,</br>Too black for heav'n, and yet too white for hell,</br>Who just dropt half way down, nor lower fell;</br>So pois'd, so gently she descends from high,</br>It seems a soft dismission from the sky.</br>Her house not ancient, whatsoe'er pretence</br>Her clergy Heraulds make in her defence;</br>A second century not half-way run,</br>Since the new honours of her bloud begun.</br>A Lyon, old, obscene, and furious made</br>By lust, compress'd her mother in a shade.</br>Then, by a left-hand marr'age, weds the Dame,</br>Cov'ring adult'ry with a specious name:</br>So schism begot; and sacrilege and she,</br>A well-match'd pair, got graceless heresie.</br>God's and kings rebels have the same good cause,</br>To trample down divine and humane laws;</br>Both wou'd be call'd Reformers, and their hate</br>Alike destructive both to church and state:</br>The fruit proclaims the plant; a lawless Prince</br>By luxury reform'd incontinence,</br>By ruins, charity; by riots, abstinence.</br>Confessions, fasts, and penance set aside;</br>Oh with what ease we follow such a guide!</br>Where souls are starv'd, and senses gratify'd.</br>Where marr'age pleasures midnight pray'r supply,</br>And mattin bells (a melancholy cry)</br>Are tun'd to merrier notes, encrease and multiply.</br>Religion shows a Rosie colour'd face;</br>Not hatter'd out with drudging works of grace,</br>A down-hill Reformation rolls apace.</br>What flesh and bloud wou'd croud the narrow gate?</br>Or, till they waste their pamper'd paunches, wait?</br>All wou'd be happy at the cheapest rate.

Though our lean faith these rigid laws has giv'n,</br>The full-fed Mussulman goes fat to heav'n;</br>For his Arabian Prophet with delights</br>Of sense, allur'd his eastern Proselytes.</br>The jolly Luther, reading him, began</br>To interpret Scriptures by his Alcoran;</br>To grub the thorns beneath our tender feet,</br>And make the paths of Paradise more sweet:</br>Bethought him of a wife e'er half way gone,</br>(For 'twas uneasy travailing alone;)</br>And, in this masquerade of mirth and love,</br>Mistook the bliss of heav'n for Bacchanals above.</br>Sure he presum'd of praise, who came to stock</br>Th' ethereal pastures with so fair a flock,</br>Burnish'd, and bat'ning on their food, to show</br>The diligence of carefull herds below.

Our Panther, though like these she chang'd her head,</br>Yet, as the mistress of a monarch's bed,</br>Her front erect with majesty she bore,</br>The Crosier wielded, and the Mitre wore.</br>Her upper part of decent discipline</br>Shew'd affectation of an ancient line:</br>And fathers, councils, church and churches head,</br>Were on her reverend Phylacteries read.</br>But what disgrac'd and disavow'd the rest,</br>Was Calvin's brand, that stigmatiz'd the beast.</br>Thus, like a creature of a double kind,</br>In her own labyrinth she lives confin'd.</br>To foreign lands no sound of Her is come,</br>Humbly content to be despis'd at home.</br>Such is her faith, where good cannot be had,</br>At least she leaves the refuse of the bad.</br>Nice in her choice of ill, though not of best,</br>And least deform'd, because reform'd the least.</br>In doubtfull points betwixt her diff'ring friends,</br>Where one for substance, one for sign contends,</br>Their contradicting terms she strives to join,</br>Sign shall be substance, substance shall be sign.</br>A real presence all her sons allow,</br>And yet 'tis flat Idolatry to bow,</br>Because the god-head's there they know not how.</br>Her Novices are taught that bread and wine</br>Are but the visible and outward sign</br>Received by those who in communion join.</br>But th' inward grace, or the thing signify'd,</br>His bloud and body, who to save us dy'd;</br>The faithfull this thing signified receive.</br>What is't those faithfull then partake or leave?</br>For, what is signify'd and understood,</br>Is, by her own confession, flesh and bloud.</br>Then, by the same acknowledgment, we know</br>They take the sign, and take the substance too.</br>The lit'ral sense is hard to flesh and blood,</br>But nonsense never can be understood.

Her wild belief on every wave is tost;</br>But sure no church can better morals boast.</br>True to her king her principles are found;</br>Oh that her practice were but half so sound!</br>Stedfast in various turns of state she stood,</br>And seal'd her vow'd affection with her bloud:</br>Nor will I meanly tax her constancy,</br>That int'rest or obligement made the tye,</br>(Bound to the fate of murdered monarchy.</br>Before the sounding Ax so falls the Vine,</br>Whose tender branches round the Poplar twine.)</br>She chose her ruin, and resign'd her life,</br>In death undaunted as an Indian wife:</br>A rare example:  but some souls we see</br>Grow hard, and stiffen with adversity:</br>Yet these by fortune's favours are undone,</br>Resolv'd into a baser form they run,</br>And bore the wind, but cannot bear the sun.</br>Let this be natures frailty or her fate,</br>Or Isgrim's counsel, her new chosen mate,</br>Still she's the fairest of the fallen crew,</br>No mother more indulgent, but the true.

Fierce to her foes, yet fears her force to try,</br>Because she wants innate auctority;</br>For how can she constrain them to obey,</br>Who has herself cast off the lawfull sway?</br>Rebellion equals all, and those, who toil</br>In common theft, will share the common spoil.</br>Let her produce the title and the right</br>Against her old superiors first to fight;</br>If she reform by Text, ev'n that's as plain</br>For her own Rebels to reform again.</br>As long as words a diff'rent sense will bear,</br>And each may be his own Interpreter,</br>Our airy faith will no foundation find,</br>The word's a weathercock for ev'ry wind:</br>The Bear, the Fox, the Wolfe, by turns prevail;</br>The most in pow'r supplies the present gale.</br>The wretched Panther cries aloud for aid</br>To church and councils, whom she first betray'd;</br>No help from Fathers or traditions train,</br>Those ancient guides she taught us to disdain.</br>And by that scripture, which she once abus'd</br>To Reformation, stands herself accus'd.</br>What bills for breach of laws can she prefer,</br>Expounding which she owns herself may err?</br>And, after all her winding ways are try'd,</br>If doubts arise she slips herself aside,</br>And leaves the private conscience for the guide.</br>If then that conscience set th' offender free,</br>It barrs her claim to Church auctority.</br>How can she censure, or what crime pretend,</br>But Scripture may be constru'd to defend?</br>Ev'n those, whom for rebellion she transmits</br>To civil pow'r, her doctrine first acquits;</br>Because no disobedience can ensue,</br>Where no submission to a Judge is due.</br>Each judging for himself by her consent,</br>Whom thus absolv'd she sends to punishment.</br>Suppose the Magistrate revenge her cause,</br>'Tis onely for transgressing humane laws.</br>How answ'ring to its end a Church is made,</br>Whose pow'r is but to counsell and persuade?</br>O solid rock, on which secure she stands!</br>Eternal house, not built with mortal hands!</br>O sure defence against th' infernal gate,</br>A patent during pleasure of the state!

Thus is the Panther neither lov'd nor fear'd,</br>A mere mock Queen of a divided Herd;</br>Whom soon by lawfull pow'r she might controll,</br>Her self a part submitted to the whole.</br>Then, as the Moon who first receives the light</br>By which she makes our nether regions bright,</br>So might she shine, reflecting from afar</br>The rays she borrow'd from a better star:</br>Big with the beams which from her mother flow</br>And reigning o'er the rising tides below:</br>Now, mixing with a salvage croud, she goes</br>And meanly flatters her invet'rate foes.</br>Rul'd while she rules, and losing every hour</br>Her wretched remnants of precarious pow'r.

One evening, while the cooler shade she sought,</br>Revolving many a melancholy thought,</br>Alone she walk'd, and look'd around in vain,</br>With ruefull visage for her vanish'd train:</br>None of her sylvan subjects made their court;</br>Levees and couchees pass'd without resort.</br>So hardly can Usurpers manage well</br>Those, whom they first instructed to rebel:</br>More liberty begets desire of more;</br>The hunger still encreases with the store.</br>Without respect, they brush'd along the wood,</br>Each in his clan, and, fill'd with loathsome food,</br>Ask'd no permission to the neighb'ring flood.</br>The Panther full of inward discontent,</br>Since they wou'd goe, before 'em wisely went:</br>Supplying want of pow'r by drinking first,</br>As if she gave 'em leave to quench their thirst.</br>Among the rest, the Hind, with fearfull face</br>Beheld from far the common wat'ring place,</br>Nor durst approach; till with an awfull roar</br>The sovereign Lyon bade her fear no more.</br>Encouraged thus she brought her younglings nigh,</br>Watching the motions of her Patron's eye,</br>And drank a sober draught; the rest amaz'd,</br>Stood mutely still, and on the stranger gaz'd:</br>Survey'd her part by part, and sought to find</br>The ten-horn'd monster in the harmless Hind,</br>Such as the Wolfe and Panther had design'd.</br>They thought at first they dream'd; for 'twas offence</br>With them, to question certitude of sense,</br>Their guide in faith; but nearer when they drew,</br>And had the faultless object full in view,</br>Lord, how they all admir'd her heavenly hiew!</br>Some, who before her fellowship disdain'd,</br>Scarce, and but scarce, from in-born rage restrain'd,</br>Now frisk'd about her, and old kindred feign'd.</br>Whether for love or int'rest, ev'ry sect</br>Of all the salvage nation shew'd respect:</br>The Viceroy Panther could not awe the herd,</br>The more the company the less they fear'd.</br>The surly Wolfe with secret envy burst,</br>Yet cou'd not howl; the Hind had seen him first:</br>But what he durst not speak, the Panther durst.

For when the herd suffis'd did late repair</br>To ferny heaths, and to their forest lare,</br>She made a mannerly excuse to stay,</br>Proff'ring the Hind to wait her half the way:</br>That, since the Sky was clear, an hour of talk,</br>Might help her to beguile the tedious walk.</br>With much good-will the motion was embrac'd,</br>To chat a while on their adventures pass'd:</br>Nor had the gratefull Hind so soon forgot</br>Her friend and fellow-suff'rer in the plot.</br>Yet wondring how of late she grew estrang'd,</br>Her forehead cloudy, and her count'nance chang'd,</br>She thought this hour th' occasion would present</br>To learn her secret cause of discontent;</br>Which, well she hop'd, might be with ease redress'd,</br>Considering Her a well-bred civil beast,</br>And more a Gentlewoman than the rest.</br>After some common talk what rumours ran,</br>The Lady of the spotted muff began.
